Sample BET surface area (m2 g−1) Average pore diameters (nm) Recovered DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH after the 8th reuse 201.69 2.05 DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH): A new magnetically separable basic nanocatalyst for the synthesis of some nucleoside-containing heterocycles Reza Kordnezhadian a Mohsen Shekouhy a ⁎ Somaye Karimian b Ali Khalafi-Nezhad a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz 71454, Iran Department of Chemistry College of Sciences Shiraz University Shiraz 71454 Iran Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz 71454, Iran b Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Shiraz, Iran Department of Medicinal Chemistry School of Pharmacy Shiraz University of Medical Sciences Shiraz Iran Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Shiraz, Iran ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) was successfully prepared as a new magnetically separable and reusable mesoporous basic nanocatalyst and characterized by various techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, HR-TEM, FESEM, BET, VSM and elemental analyses (CHN and ICP-OES). The prepared nanocatalyst was then successfully applied for the synthesis of some nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines, [2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidine and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolines via one-pot multicomponent reactions under solvent-free conditions. In all cases, applied catalyst was recovered and reused several times without any changes in chemical and physical structures as well as the catalytic activity. The biggest achievement of this research is the conversion of DBU as a widely used catalyst in organic synthesis from a toxic, not-recyclable and funky liquid to a recoverable and reusable solid material with the same catalytic characters. Keywords Nucleoside Multicomponent reaction Nanocatalyst MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite 1,8-Diazabicyclo(5.4.0)undec-7-ene Nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidine Nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidine Nucleoside-containing pyrimido[4,5-b]quinoline 1 Introduction The pioneering of Green Chemistry leads to an emergency need for novel catalytic systems which provide higher selectivity and reactivity, better yields and also simple and effective separation and reuse of the catalyst [1]. All types of catalysts can be divided into homogeneous and heterogeneous species. A homogeneous catalyst provides some unique advantages such as good activity and selectivity and accessible mechanistic studies leading to catalyst optimization. However, the difficulty of separating homogeneous catalysts from reaction media consumedly restricts their applications in industry, especially in the drug and pharmaceutical industry. The most useful method to overcome this failure is the heterogenization of active molecules with a solid support fabricating insoluble material. However, the activities of heterogeneous catalysts are generally lower than those of their homogeneous counterparts, due to the lower dimensionality of the interaction between the components and the catalyst surface. Nanocatalysts, as considerable candidates for the fulfillment of the Green Chemistry protocols, prepare high accessible surface area-to-volume ratios which in turn enhance the catalytic activity. The use of less amounts of these catalysts makes them comparatively more cost-effective and also prevents disposal of hazardous materials into the environment which is of paramount importance from the Green Chemistry perspective. Additionally, the features of nanocatalysts such as size, shape, composition and morphology could be manipulated as required [2]. Due to these remarkable merits, different kinds of nanocatalysts have been applied for several prominent industrial chemical processes such as water purification [3–5], biodiesel production [6–8], photocatalysis [9,10], drug delivery [11–13], etc. Nevertheless, the separation and recovery steps for nanocatalysts require ultrafiltration and high speed centrifugation methods. In addition to costing a lot, these tedious methods are not completely efficient and this is in the opposition of Green Chemistry principles of the prevention (protocol No. 1) and energy efficiency (protocol No. 6). It is not a false claim if we say the most preferred method to overcome this issue is the magnetization of nanocatalysts. Magnetic nanocatalysts are simply and efficiently removed from reaction mixtures with an external magnetic field. Because of this unique characteristic, the magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) have emerged as ideal catalysts or supports and there are so many reports about the design, preparation and application of magnetic nanocatalysts in organic syntheses and this field has indeed been the subject of excellent reviews [14]. The Hematite (α-Fe2O3) is the most stable iron oxide provides some unique properties such as high resistance to corrosion, low cost, environmentally friendliness and non-toxicity [15,16]. These unique properties have made the hematite a special focus of researchers and there are numerous reports about its application in catalysis, gas sensors, pigments, solar cells, lithium-ion batteries, magnetic and antibacterial materials [17–23]. One of the most important characteristics of hematite is its magnetism. The bulk hematite is a weak ferromagnet below the Néel temperature TN (from 948 to 963 K) that undergoes a magnetic phase transition at the Morin temperature TM (approximately 263 K) to a purely antiferromagnetic phase at lower temperatures [15]. It is well known that the hematite magnetic properties depend on the particle size and display the most interesting effects when the size of the particles decreases below 20 nm. The Morin temperature decreases with decreasing the particle size and it disappears as the particle size shrinks by 10 nm [24,25]. On the other hand, the Néel temperature reduces with the decreasing particle size [26]. When the size of hematite particles is small enough, due to the thermal agitation, the fluctuation of the magnetic moment direction in a single domain occurs, leading to superparamagnetic behavior above the blocking temperature TB, and to spatial freezing of these moments below TB [27,28]. There are several reports about the study of the relationship between the particle size of hematite and its magnetic properties. These studies have shown that the magnetic properties especially Morin transition, the Néel temperature and superparamagnetic relaxation of the nanoparticles are significantly affected by the hematite particle sizes [28,29]. Between various kinds of nanomaterials have been used as supports for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts, mesoporous silicates specially MCM-41 with very high surface area to volume ratios and tunable pore size diameters provide ideal conditions to produce more effective catalysts. There are various reported nanocatalysts based on MCM-41 with the modification of the surface (immobilization of homogeneous catalysts, impregnation of mesoporous surface by active metal compounds) or the modification of mesoporous framework (insertion of metal ions in the mesoporous framework) [14h–i]. To the best of our knowledge, there are not any reports on the modification of the mesoporous compounds surface with a base moiety to prepare a basic mesoporous nanocatalytic system. Amongst numerous alternatives to the traditional corrosive non-recoverable basic catalysts (such as NaOH, KOH, etc.), 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) is a remarkable promising point which possesses some advantages like appropriate basicity and non-nucleophilicity [30,31]. Holding exceptional advantages, DBU has become a renowned basic catalyst which has being applied for organic reactions so far [32–35]. Nonetheless, from an environmental point of view, the application of DBU in organic transformations is in combination with some important drawbacks which hamper its further applications. For example, DBU is a funky, volatile and highly toxic liquid (DBU LD50 = 189 mg kg−1, oral rat) which is almost no recoverable and leads to the formation of harmful wastes [36a-j]. There are a few reports about the conversion of DBU to different solid recoverable and reusable catalytic systems with the support of DBU on polymers with higher molecular weights [36k,37,38]. Nucleosides, either naturally occurring or synthetic, play an important role in the research field of medicinal chemistry due to their numerous biological activities such as anti-cancer, anti-viral, etc. [39–41] and they are also extensively used in the treatment of some diseases (Fig. 1 ) [42]. However, because of drug-resistant mutants, routinely used commercial nucleoside drugs lose their impacts which as a consequence, this issue engenders an ongoing demand for the preparation of new derivatives that can be used for the optimization process of biological active compounds [43,44]. For this purpose, some strategies have being introduced since late 1970s [44]. One of the methods that has recently been used is the multicomponent reaction (MCRs) which produces the desired product in one step [36,45–47]. Though the synthesis of nucleoside-containing organic compounds through the multicomponent reactions provide a practical and fast strategy to prepare a widespread library of desired compounds, but there are only two reports on the direct application of nucleosides as starting materials in multicomponent synthesis of heterocycles and both of them are reported by our research group [36k,45]. So there is a demand to introduce more efficient and practical methods for the direct application of nucleosides in multicomponent reactions. Considering these facts, in the sequel of our recent studies on the design, preparation and application of more benign, efficient and reusable catalysts for the synthesis of organic compounds [48], and in the sequel of our recent efforts to convert the DBU as a liquid non-reusable base catalyst to a more benign solid reusable catalytic system [36k], we herein report the preparation and characterization of DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) (1) as a new highly efficient, heterogeneous magnetically separable and reusable mesoporous nanocatalyst and its efficiency for the direct application of nucleosides in the multicomponent synthesis of some nucleoside-containing heterocycles (7aa-bu) (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 General information All chemicals were purchased from Fluka, Merck and Sigma-Aldrich chemical companies. The reaction monitoring was accomplished by TLC on silica gel PolyGram SILG/ UV254 plates. The eluent solvents were petroleum ether, ethyl acetate or a mixture of them. All yields refer to isolated products after indicated purification methods. The products were characterized by their spectral data analysis. Melting points were determined in open capillary tubes with a Büchi B-545 melting point apparatus. 1H NMR (250 MHz) and 13C NMR (62.5 MHz) spectra were run on Bruker Avance DRX in pure CDCl3 or DMSO‑d6 solvents. Chemical shifts are given in the δ scale in part per million (ppm) and J in Hz. IR spectroscopy was done with Shimadzu FT-IR 8300 and Perkin Elemer FT-IR RX 1 spectrophotometer. Microanalysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240-B microanalyzer. The inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was determined using an ICP analyzer (Varian, Vista-Pro). XRD patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer using nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Scanning Electron Micrograms (SEM) was obtained using KYKY-EM3200 Instrument. The high resolution transmittance electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was performed with JEOL, JEM-2100F, 200 KV TEM. VSM curves were recorded by Vibrating Sample Magnetometer Model VSM 4 Daghigh Meghnatis Kashan Co. The dynamic light scattering analysis was done with a SZ-100 Horiba (Japan) analyzer. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K by micrometritics instrument model Asap2020. 2.2 The synthesis of 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) Anhydrous DBU (10 mmol, 1.52 g) was added to dry tetrahydrofuran (50 mL) under the nitrogen atmosphere in a 250 mL three neck round-bottom flask equipped by a dropping funnel. The n-butyllithium in n-hexane (15 mmol, 2.66 M) was slowly added from the dropping funnel (10 min) at 0 °C, and the mixture was magnetically stirred for 1 h. Then, (3-chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane (10 mmol, 1.98 g) in tetrahydrofuran (25 mL) was slowly added from the dropping funnel (10 min) and the mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. After this time, in order to quench the mixture, methanol (ca. 20 mL) was added, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and the resulting viscous oil (pale yellow) was washed by diethyl ether (25 mL, 2 times), dried under reduced pressure for 24 h and the desired product was obtained as a yellow viscous oil (98%, 3.08 g). 1H NMR (250 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 0.59 (t, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 0.87–1.03 (m, 4H), 1.57–1.83 (m, 8H), 2.33–2.41 (m, 1H), 3.17–3.27 (m, 6H), 3.50 (s, 9H). 2.3 The synthesis of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles FeCl3·6H2O (20 mmol, 5.40 g) and FeCl2·4H2O (10 mmol, 1.98 g) were dissolved in deionized water (30 mL). The solution was heated to 60 °C under nitrogen gas and vigorous mechanical stirring with a glassware stirrer for 30 min, followed by the slow addition of a NaOH solution (1.5 M, 250 mL). During the whole process, the solution temperature was maintained at 60 °C and pH was kept above 10.0. Then, the obtained precipitate was separated from the reaction medium by an external magnet and washed by deionized water (100 mL, 4 times). The obtained solid was dried under reduced pressure for 24 h and Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were obtained as dark brown solid (2.29 g). 2.4 The synthesis of MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles The synthesis of MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles was carried out using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the Si source, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the surfactant template, Fe3O4 nanoparticles as the magnetic core and ammonia as the pH control agent with gel composition of Si:Fe:CTAB:NH4OH:H2O = 1.00:0.075:0.127:0.623:508. In a typical synthesis procedure, Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (0.13 g) was dispersed in deionized water (200 mL) under sonication during 15 min, then, CTAB (1.04 g) was dissolved in this solution under stirring using mechanical mixer. The mixture temperature was increased up to 60 °C and kept at this temperature for 15 min. TEOS (22.5 mmol, ≈4.66 g) was added dropwise to the obtained mixture and the pH was adjusted to 10.5 by adding 25 wt% ammonia solution and obtained mixture was stirred mechanically using a glassware stirrer for 12 h at room temperature. The gel was separated by an external magnet and washed by ethanol (5 mL, three times) and deionized water (10 mL, three times). The solid was dried at 120 °C for 2 h and calcinated in air at 550 °C for 4 h to give MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles as an orange brown powder (1.40 g). 2.5 The synthesis of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH In a double neck round-bottom flask equipped by a mechanical stirrer and a condenser, anhydrous toluene (25 mL) and dehydrated purely MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (1.00 g) were added and insoluble particles were truly dispersed by sonication for 20 min. After this time, 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (2 mmol, 0.62 g) and pyridine (0.5 mmol, ≈0.04 g) were added and resulting mixture was vigorously stirred using a glassware mechanical stirrer at reflux temperature for 6 h. After this time, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the powder was separated by an external magnet, washed by ethanol (20 mL, three times) and water (20 mL, three times) and dried at 120 °C for 4 h. DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH was obtained as an orange brown powder (1.28 g). 2.6 The general procedure for the one-pot multicomponent synthesis of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (7aa-az), pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolones (7bo-bu) in the presence of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH Carbonyl compounds (2, 1 mmol), barbituric acid (4, 1 mmol, 0.128 g), nucleosides (3a-d, 1 mmol) and malononitrile (5, 1 mmol, 0.06 g)/barbituric acid (4, 1 mmol, 0.128 g)/dimedone (6, 1 mmol, 0.14 g) were added in a 10 mL round-bottom flask contained DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (20 mg) and two drops of water. The resulting mixture was stirred at 80 °C and the progress of the reaction was followed by TLC. After the completion of the reaction, hot ethanol (20 mL) was added and obtained mixture was boiled for 5 min. Then, the insoluble catalyst was separated from the solution by an external magnet, washed well by hot ethanol (5 mL, 2 times), dried at 120 °C and kept for another use (0.019 g of the catalyst was recovered successfully). The hot solution of crude products in ethanol was kept at room temperature over the night and during this time, pure desired products were slowly precipitated. 3 Results and discussion At the beginning, 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) was synthesized by the reaction of in situ formed 7-lithium-1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (9) and (3-chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane (10) in dry THF (Scheme 2 ). The structure of the synthesized 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) was demonstrated by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Supplementary data, Figure S1). In the 1H NMR spectrum of 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11), hydrogen nuclei α to silicon appeared as a triplet in 0.59 ppm. Hydrogen nuclei β and γ to silicon appeared as multiplets between 0.87 and 1.03 ppm. Hydrogen nuclei connected to carbons no. 3, 4, 5 and 10 in DBU moiety appeared as a multiplet between 1.57 and 1.83 ppm. Hydrogen nucleus connected to carbon no. 6 in DBU moiety appeared as a multiplet between 2.33 and 2.41 ppm. Hydrogen nuclei connected to carbons no. 9 and 11 in DBU moiety appeared as a multiplet between 3.17 and 3.27 ppm and hydrogen nuclei of three methoxy groups appeared as singlet in 3.50 ppm. In the next step, the magnetically separable mesoporous support (the MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite) was prepared with the formation of MCM-41 around the γ-Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (12) and calcination at 550 °C under the air atmosphere. For this, MCM-41-coated γ-Fe3O4 nanoparticles were synthesized at room temperature with the use of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (13) as the Si source, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the surfactant template, γ-Fe3O4 nanoparticles (12) as the magnetic core and ammonia as the pH control agent with gel composition of Si: Fe: CTAB: NH4OH: H2O = 1.00: 0.075: 0.127: 0.623: 508 followed with the calcination at 550 °C under the air atmosphere. During the calcination step, the γ-Fe3O4 nanoparticles (dark brown solid) were changed to the α-Fe2O3 (brown orange solid) as it has been reported with some other research groups [49]. Finally, 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) and MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were refluxed in toluene in the presence of pyridine and DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) was obtained as a brown orange solid (1) (Scheme 3 ). The freshly synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH was characterized by various techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, HR-TEM, FESEM, BET, VSM and elemental analyses (CHN and ICP-OES). In the FT-IR spectrum of synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1), the peak in the region of 550–630 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations of the FeO bonds in α-Fe2O3 and the peak at about 1080–1200 cm−1 belongs to SiO stretching vibrations. The weak peak appearing at 1463 cm−1 is due to the bending vibration of the CH bonds. The peak at 1645 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of CN bonds. The peaks around 2930 cm−1 are related to stretching vibrations of the sp3 CH bonds. The broad peak appeared at 3429 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations of OH bonds on the surface of MCM-41 (Fig. 2 ). The XRD patterns of the synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) are presented in Fig. 3 . The XRD analysis was performed from <2.0° (2θ) to 10.0° (2θ) (Fig. 3, a) and 10.0° (2θ) to 80.0° (2θ) (Fig. 3, b). In the low angle XRD, the main peak related to the [1 0 0] reflection of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) as a main characteristic of mesoporous compounds is observed in 2θ = 2.20°. In addition, the position of all the peaks in the region of 10.0° (2θ) to 80.0° (2θ) coincide with the maxima characteristic of the hematite phase (JCPDS card 33-0664) and no diffraction line corresponding to other phases has been observed, indicating high purity of the sample. This data confirms the change of γ-Fe3O4 to α-Fe2O3 during the calcination step. In order to investigate the morphology and particle size of the synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1), the Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) was performed and the result was depicted in Fig. 4 a. The FESEM image shows approximately uniformed and spherical nanoparticles with sizes <100 nm (Fig. 4a). According to the Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) analysis results, the particle size of synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH ranging from 60 to 90 nm with the average size of 80 nm (Fig. 4b). The mesostructure of the synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) was investigated by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and the results were depicted in Fig. 5 . In the HR-TEM images, porosity of the sample is observed in the range of mesoporous materials. Moreover, the HR-TEM images show the embedded cores of the α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles with the sizes ranging from 5 to 10 nm and an average size of 8 nm. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the pure MCM-41 (previously prepared by our research group), MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 magnetic NPs (15) and DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) are exhibited in Fig. 6 and the textural properties are summarized in Table 1 . The reported results in Table 1 show that the BET surface area and pore diameter of the MCM-41 substantially are decreased by the entrance of α-Fe2O3 in the MCM-41 framework from 1177 m2 g−1 and 2.47 nm to 847 m2 g−1 and 2.31 nm respectively. Similarly, the BET surface area and pore diameter of the final catalyst (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) are decreased by immobilization of 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) on the surface of MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 magnetic nanoparticles (15) from 847 m2 g−1 and 2.31 nm to 205 m2 g−1 and 2.01 nm respectively. These results confirm the insertion of magnetic nanoparticles in the framework of MCM-41 and also immobilization of 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) on the surface of prepared magnetic support (15). Recently, Tadic et al. have prepared and characterized an iron oxide nanochains coated with silica [50]. As it is demonstrated in Table 1, the pore diameters of this composite is higher than the freshly synthesized DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH, however, the BET surface area is significantly lower than DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH which proves the effectiveness of applied method the present manuscript for the construction of a magnetically separable mesoporous material with high available surface area. Magnetic measurements were carried out using a vibrating sample magnetometer instrument (VSM) at 300 K. The magnetization curves were measured and magnetization versus applied magnetic field is shown for MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 Magnetic NPs (15) (A) and DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) (B) in Fig. 7 . It is well known for the superparamagnetic state under an applied magnetic field H = 0, the magnetization of each magnetic particle points in different directions and the overall magnetic moment is zero [51]. As shown in Fig. 7, no hysteresis loop and no remanence (M r300K = 0) was detected and also the coercivity value is zero (H C300K = 0) for both samples, suggesting typical superparamagnetic property at room temperature. The saturation magnetization values of nanoparticles was found to be equal to 4 and 2 emu/g for MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 Magnetic NPs (15) and DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) respectively. The saturation magnetization value of the DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) (2 emu/g) is lower than that value for MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 Magnetic NPs (15) (4 emu/g) due to the relative less magnetization per unit of mass in the former sample and this also verifies the immobilization of 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11) on the surface of prepared magnetic support (15). Additionally, the magnetic separability of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) is further studied in reaction media through a separation and re-dispersion process by placing an external magnet near the reaction mixture vessel. The magnetic NPs were attracted towards the magnet within a short period of time, and when the external magnet is removed, they will be re-dispersed in the solution by a slight shake (Fig. 8 ). The ICP-OES analysis showed that Si/Fe molar ratio is equal to 14.45. The results obtained from CHN elemental analysis (%C = 18.01, %H = 2.92, %N = 3.70) reveals that DBU loading level is equal to 1.25 mmol per gram of the final catalyst. After successful preparation and characterization of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1), in order to figure out its ability to play as a heterogeneous recoverable base catalyst, its catalytic efficiency was studied for the synthesis of some nucleoside-containing heterocycles via the one-pot multicomponent condensation of carbonyl compounds (2), nucleosides (3a-d), barbituric acid (4) and a C-H acid compound (malononitrile (5) in the case of pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines synthesis, barbituric acid (4) in the case of pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines synthesis or dimedone (6) for the synthesis of pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolones) (Scheme 1). Initially, to find the best reaction conditions, the one-pot four-component reaction of benzlaldehyde (2a), adenosine (3), barbituric acid (4) and malononitrile (5) was selected as a model reaction (Scheme 4 ). The reaction yields and times were recorded under various conditions including different reaction media, various amount of the catalyst and different temperatures and obtained results were summarized in Table 2 . Firstly, in order to choose an appropriate media for the reaction, different solvents such as tetrahydrofuran, dichloromethane, chloroform, acetonitrile, ethyl acetate, methanol, ethanol, water, mixture of ethanol/water (1:1 v/v) and solvent-free condition were tested (Table 2, entries 1–10) and the best results were obtained in the absence of solvent (Table 2, entry 10), probably due to the increase in the effective contacts and collisions between the reactants caused by the increase in the concentration and removing the solvent barrier. Then, the optimization process of the reaction conditions was screened by allowing the reaction to proceed using different amounts of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) as catalyst (Table 2, entries 10 and 12–16). As it can be seen in Table 2, 20 mg of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) catalyzed the reaction in the most efficient way and produced the highest yield of the product in the shortest reaction time (Table 2, entry 10). An increase in the amount of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) to more than 20 mg showed no substantial improvement in the yield (Table 2, entries 15 and 16), whereas the yield decreased by reducing the amount of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) to less than 20 mg (Table 2, entries 12–14). Moreover, it was observed that the reaction did not proceed at all in the absence of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) even after 24 h (Table 2, entry 11) and this issue displays the essential role of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) in the advancing of the reaction time and the product yield. Subsequently, the reaction temperature was checked (Table 2, entries 10 and 17–20). As the obtained results show, increasing the temperature to more than 80 °C did not improve the yield and the reaction time (Table 2, entry 20), whereas the yield decreased and reaction time increased by the decreasing the temperature to less than 80 °C (Table 2, entries 17–19). Finally, to show the efficiency of the support on the catalytic activity of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1), the model reaction was carried out in the presence of 20 mg MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (15) under the optimized condition and much less yield of the product compared to the optimized reaction conditions was obtained after 24 h (Table 2, entry 21). Moreover, the model reaction was studied in the presence of DBU (20 mol%) at 80 °C under solvent-free conditions and approximately similar results with the results of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH was obtained (Table 2, entry 22). In spite of the fact that the application of DBU as a commercial available catalyst is operationally much easier than synthesizing DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH, the DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH is a more competent catalytic system because the liquid form of DBU makes the separation of this material a highly tedious procedure as DBU must be removed as a residue that is a combination of biohazards. The covalent bonding of DBU to MCM-41-coated α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles converts DBU to a new solid and stable material that is an easily separable and reusable efficient base catalyst that has the basic properties of DBU and the advantages of a magnetically separable nanocatalyst and high available surface area of MCM-41 at the same time. Therefore, after a comprehensive investigation, the best yield and time profile for the model reaction were obtained using 20 mg of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH under solvent-free condition at 80 °C, which led to the production of the corresponding product (7aa) in 92% yield within 7.5 h (Table 2, entry 10). With optimization results in hand, in order to evaluate the scope and efficiency of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) in direct application of nucleosides as starting materials in multicomponent synthesis, nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (7aa-az), pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolines (7bo-bu) were synthesized using various carbonyl compounds (2, 1 mmol), nucleosides (3, 1 mmol), barbituric acid (4, 1 mmol) and malononitrile (5)/barbituric acid (4)/dimedone (6) (1 mmol) through one-pot multicomponent reactions under optimized conditions (Scheme 1). The obtained results are listed in Table 3 . As tabulated results show, all reactions proceeded efficiently using different nucleosides (3a-d) and the desired products (7aa-7bu) were produced in good to excellent yields (81–94%) in relatively short reaction times (5–22 h) without formation of any by-products. However, aromatic aldehydes having electron withdrawing groups reacted at faster rates in comparison with the rest. It is noteworthy that our methodology has been used successfully in order of applying acid-sensitive starting materials such as 4-cyanobenzaldehyde without any decomposition or polymerization (Table 3, entries 11, 17, 20, 34, 39 and 45). Interestingly, this method was also found to be practical for the utilization of cyclic ketones such as isatin derivatives (2o and 2p) or ninhydrin (2q) as starting materials for the synthesis of nucleoside-containing spiro pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (Table 3, entries 22–26). What is more, in order to further extension of applicability and versatility of the catalyst in direct application of nucleosides as starting materials in a multicomponent synthesis, nucleoside- containing [2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) (Table 3, entries 28–40) and nucleoside-containing pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolines (7bo-bu) (Table 3, entries 41–47) were synthesized with highly satisfying results. We suggest herein a plausible mechanism for the synthesis of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (7aa-az) in the presence of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) which explains the reaction selectivity (Schemes 5 and 6 ). First of all, it must be noted that Xiao et al. showed that DBU catalyzes the condensation of ethyl diazoacetate with aldehydes only in water as a reaction medium. They concluded that the reaction can proceed effectively with 30% DBU in water but they did not explain why the water is necessary [50]. In 2008, Medina et al. studied the DBU-H2O system as a catalyst for several aldol condensation reactions. The role of the addition of water has been studied using RMN tests which demonstrated that water reacts with DBU and changes the DBU structure to a second resonance structure contains protonated DBU and hydroxide ion and this second resonance structure of DBU is responsible for the catalytic activity in aldol condensation reactions [31]. We also think that at the first step, the DBU moiety of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) reacts with water and produces a second structure that contains protonated DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (21) and hydroxide ion and this second structure is the active catalyst under this applied condition (Scheme 5). According to our proposed mechanism, the water-reacted form of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (21) is an effective catalyst showing dual activation role. First, protonated DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (21) activates electrophiles through a hydrogen bond interaction between the protonated part of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (21) and the oxygen of the carbonyl groups and nitrogen of nitrile group, as shown in Scheme 6. And second, hydroxide ion activates nucleophiles through deprotonation of C-H acids. Moreover, hydroxide ion enhances nucleophilicity of nucleosides (2) via a hydrogen bond between hydroxide ion and nitrogen atom of amine group of nucleoside. At the first step, cyano olefin intermediate (16) is formed in situ from Knoevenagel condensation reaction of carbonyl compound (2) with highly active C-H acidic malononitrile (5) after removing one molecule of water. At the next step, barbituric acid (4) in the presence of protonated DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (16) converts to its corresponding enolate form (18) and adds to the cyano olefin intermediate (17) by Michael reaction to produce the next intermediate (19). Then, the nucleoside as a nucleophile, attacks to that intermediate (19) and afterward, an intramolecular cyclization occurs to produce the imine-containing intermediate (20). After this, an imine-enamine tautomeric proton shift gives the desired product (7aa-az). Finally, the water-reacted form of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (16) is released out for another next cycle. The plausible mechanisms for the synthesis of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolones (7bo-bu) in the presence DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1) closely resemble to the plausible mechanism for the synthesis of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (7aa-az). The main difference is in step 1 which barbituric acid (4) and dimedone (6) in the case of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolones (7bo-bu) respectively is deprotonated in the presence of the water-reacted form of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (16) and undergoes the Knoevenagel condensation. The rest of steps run similarly to the plausible steps for the synthesis of nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines (7aa-az) (Scheme 6). It is known that the reaction of carbonyl compounds with derivatives of cyanoacetic acid gives 3-cyanopyridine-2(1H)-ones (22) and 2,6-dicyanoanilines (23) as by-products. Meanwhile, the hydrolysis of the nitrile group leads to the formation of by-product 24 (Scheme 7 ). A distinct characteristic of the method that is illustrated in this work is the formation of desired products (7aa-7bu) without any possible by-products. To establish the reusability of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH (1), the model reaction was studied in the presence of the recovered catalyst under optimized conditions. After the completion of the reaction, hot ethanol (20 mL) was added and the obtained mixture was boiled for 5 min, the insoluble catalyst was separated from the solution by an external magnet, washed well by hot ethanol (5 mL, 2 times), dried at 120 °C and kept for another use. The recovered catalyst was reused eight times without any loss of catalytic activity (Fig. 9 ). In order to investigate the chemical and physical stability of the catalyst, its chemical and physical structure was studied using FT-IR, XRD, HR-TEM, FESEM, BET and elemental analyses (CHN and ICP-OES) after the 8th reuse. As it can be seen in Fig. 10 , there are no significant differences between the FT-IR spectrum of the recovered catalyst after 8th reuse and the FT-IR spectrum of the freshly synthesized catalyst shown in Fig. 2. The XRD analysis was performed from <2.0° (2θ) to 10.0° (2θ) for the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse (Fig. 11 ). Obviously, there are not any discernible differences between the XRD pattern of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse and that of the freshly synthesized catalyst shown in Fig. 3a. The FESEM image of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse shows uniformed and spherical encapsulated nanoparticles with sizes <100 nm (Fig. 12 ) and this issue demonstrates that the catalyst retains its unique morphology even after the 8th reuse. In HR-TEM image, porosity of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse is still observed in the range of mesoporous materials (Fig. 13 ) and similarly with HR-TEM image of the freshly synthesized catalyst shown in Fig. 5, embedded cores of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles can be seen yet. The textural properties of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse were studied by BET method. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse are presented in Fig. 14 and the textural properties summarized in Table 4 . The obtained textural properties of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms approximates the textural properties of the freshly synthesized catalyst. The ICP-OES analysis of the recovered catalyst after the 8th reuse showed that the Si/Fe molar ratio is equal to 14.38 which is so close to the same ratio as the freshly synthesized catalyst (Si/Fe = 14.45). The results obtained from the CHN elemental analysis (%C = 18.30, %H = 3.06, %N = 3.15) are also close to the CHN elemental analysis of the freshly synthesized catalyst (%C = 18.01, %H = 2.92, %N = 3.70). So it is expressible from the obtained results that the physical and chemical structures of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH are stable under the applied conditions even after the eight times of reuse. Recently, we introduced a new surfactant-combined base catalyst through the covalent bonding of DBU to polyethylene glycol (PEG-DBU) and its successful application for the use of nucleosides as reagent in multi-component synthesis of 8-substituted pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidine-6-carbonitriles in water [37 k]. The most important thing that distinguishes PEG-DBU from the catalyst provided in this article (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) is the purpose on which these catalysts are designed. In the design of both catalytic systems, there is a common goal and that is the conversion of DBU as a non-recyclable liquid base catalyst with widespread applications in organic synthesis to a solid recyclable catalytic system with the aim of avoidance the environmental pollutions. However, the PEG-DBU is a homogeneous surfactant-combined catalytic system that was prepared for the conduction of base-catalyzed organic reactions in water as a safe reaction medium, whereas, DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH is a completely heterogeneous catalytic system that was designed for the conduction of organic reactions under solvent-free conditions and any other reaction media. It is important to note that the heterogeneous and homogeneous catalytic systems differ in performance and each of them provides numerous advantages that makes a researcher choose one based on the requirements of designed synthetic pathways. In addition, there are some important improvements in the current study: a) the nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidines (7ba-bn) and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolines (7bo-bu) were constructed successfully with highly satisfying results with the application of DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH, while the synthesis of these compounds in the presence of PEG-DBU in water was not possible despite the many efforts our research group made. Therefore, the generality of the synthesis has been enhanced and the products have greatly been diversified by applying DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH as the catalyst. b) the DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH as a heterogeneous magnetically separable catalyst makes the recovery and separation of the catalyst more easy and applied catalyst is more readily and efficiently removed from the reaction mixtures with only a simple external magnetic field. c) as a result of being in nano size as well as providing high accessible surface area-to-volume ratio and efficiency, DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH is applied in one-thirtieth (1:30) as less as PEG-DBU is applied for the same reaction of the same scale (1 mmol), leading to more cost-effectiveness and prevention of chemicals disposal into the environment. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge this is the first report about the functionalization of (3-chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane before its connection to the support during the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts with the application of silica as a support. 4 Conclusion So briefly, DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH was prepared as a new, highly efficient, selective, magnetically separable and reusable nanosized mesoporous catalyst. The catalyst structure was investigated by FT-IR, XRD, FESEM, HR-TEM, BET, VSM, CHN and ICP-OES. Then a various range of starting materials, especially nucleosides, were directly applied in one-pot multicomponent synthesis of nucleoside-containing heterocycles and a high diversity of products were produced at enhanced rates and high isolated yields. One of the most promising points of this procedure is the conversion of DBU from a toxic, non-recyclable and funky liquid to a recoverable and reusable solid which in conjunction with the other merits including operational simplicity, not using of solvents, clean reaction profile, no formation of by-products and chemical stability of the catalyst fulfills some of the Green Chemistry protocols. The moderate pore sizes and high surface area as well as good colloidal stability and magnetic responsiveness of such synthesized magnetic mesoporous composite provides a potency for future applications in biomedicine. 5 Associated contents The spectral data of the synthesized nucleoside-containing compounds (7aa-bu), the copy of 1H and 13C NMR of new compounds and 10-(3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)-2,3,4,6,7,8,9,10-octahydropyrimido[1,2-a]azepine (11), all of these materials are available in supporting information. coredata.dc:description: DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH) was successfully prepared as a new magnetically separable and reusable mesoporous basic nanocatalyst and characterized by various techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, HR-TEM, FESEM, BET, VSM and elemental analyses (CHN and ICP-OES). The prepared nanocatalyst was then successfully applied for the synthesis of some nucleoside-containing pyrido[2,3-d]pyrimidines, [2,3-d:6,5-d′]dipyrimidine and pyrimido[4,5-b]quinolines via one-pot multicomponent reactions under solvent-free conditions. In all cases, applied catalyst was recovered and reused several times without any changes in chemical and physical structures as well as the catalytic activity. The biggest achievement of this research is the conversion of DBU as a widely used catalyst in organic synthesis from a toxic, not-recyclable and funky liquid to a recoverable and reusable solid material with the same catalytic characters.
coredata.dc:title: DBU-functionalized MCM-41-coated nanosized hematite (DBU-F-MCM-41-CNSH): A new magnetically separable basic nanocatalyst for the synthesis of some nucleoside-containing heterocycles
